Symbiote

The candidate
 
 www.ronpaul2008.com
 
 Ron Paul is a paleoconservative/libertarian/constitutionalist, and is running on that platform, with a remarkably consistent record of voting according to principle in congress backing it up.
 
 He has delivered over 4000 babies as an obstetrician/gynaecologist, served 5 years as a flight surgeon for the air force during vietnam, and has several times defeated incumbents to win his seat in congress.
 
 The key platform he is campaigning on isBring the troops home from Iraq, and other foreign nations, as soon as possible
 Abolish the federal reserve
 Abolish the IRS
 Abolish federal involvement in education
 Those ideas may appear radical, people now being accustomed to the feds overseeing just about everything, but he bases his positions on the constitution, something I don't think any other candidate in either party can claim to.
 
 The debates
 The main issue focused on has been the rapid withdrawal of US troops from foreign soil, a position which has provided the only really heated moments of the debates, with other candidates often interjecting to try and bolster their own credentials as "commanders in chief".
 
 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Hfa7vT02lA - first debate
 
 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XyGKmqk7Khg - third debate (edit: better video)
 
 Following the debates, he has always come in either first or second in text message and internet polls about viewers' preferred candidates, often by enormous margins.
 
 The internet
 
 The amazing thing about this campaign is that it is virtually entirely driven by a grassroots internet campaign, not flashy websites and paid advertisements, but a decentralised word of mouth effort revolving around blogs, youtube videos and meetup organisations.
 
 If the internet held an election, he would win by a wide margin, and that margin appears to be growing every day.
 
 His campaign website has had more hits than any other republican's since close to the beginning of the electoral campaigns, perhaps triple whoevers is in 2nd place now, and he recently overtook Obama to have the most hits of any campaign website. Not just that, but the growth on the demand for him is growing exponentially.
 
 Blog posts and youtube videos relating to him are consistently among the most popular and most viewed on the net, certainly within political categories, he's consistently the top searched or near top searched item on www.technorati.com and on google. His meetup groups (people organise on the internet to meet up in real life, for example to plan campaign measures etc) far exceed in size those of any other candidate in either party, he wins virtually every online poll, and anyone attempting to smear him is likely to receive a veritable flood of critical blog comments or emails correcting the issue.
 
 But how does that translate into real world success? So far, it's difficult to say. Polls show his randomised-home-phone call support has steadily shifted up from a measly 1% to a mediocre 3%, but his supporters are without a doubt the most passionate and motivated of the lot, and his support is disproportionately high in the tech-savvy individualistic crowd that doesn't own home phones, normally call themselves a republican, or have a listed number.
 
 An example of this online success translating into the "real world" is in Tennessee, where literally overnight he was catapulted onto the media through the actions of independently acting volunteers who placed hundreds of banners and signs all over town. Combined with his performance in the recent debate, this has some of the mainstream media calling his campaign the "Ron Paul phenomenon sweeping our nation", where previously he would either be ignored or declared kooky and "without a chance". In the last week approximately 10,000 individuals have signed on as volunteers for his campaign. Of course, the signage effort was recorded on youtube, and other volunteers around the US encouraged to emulate it.
 
 
 The first real test I suppose will be the Iowa straw poll, a state where Ron Paul has put little campaign effort into. Undoubtedly it will be the resident mormon who wins the straw poll there in a few days, but I think Paul's showing will be stronger than anticipated, certainly more than the 3% found in the mainstream polling.
 
 And I really think this man is America's last hope if it wants to remain or return to a constitutional republic, there is no one else like him, with the same integrity and commitment to principle, in a position to do anything about it, and the next 4 years will be critical. If the neoconservatives, or their democratic cousins inherit the power Bush has usurped, continue debasing the currency and creating resentment around the world, it may be too to ever turn back. Perhaps it already is, but so long as the internet at least remains one of the last bastions of free speech, I suppose there is still hope.
 
 I certainly encourage any Americans reading to at least consider his views, watch the debates, and decide carefully, because this is too important a decision to make carelessly.
